importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the ongoing flooding crisis in Mexico, signaling the current state of emergency and response efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding began just before the 12th, with impacts escalating over a five-day period, highlighting the rapid development and severity of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting up to 48 deaths.
The flooding was caused by heavy rains from the remnants of Tropical Storm Raymond and Hurricane Priscilla, which impacted five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Specific death tolls per state include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and around 320,000 have experienced power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The Mexican government has mobilized the military to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, emphasizing national commitment to humanitarian support.
Mexico City experienced its rainiest June in over two decades, indicating a broader climate trend of increased rainfall.
The remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond contributed to the downpours, with Raymond’s remnants expected to affect southern Baja California on the day of reporting.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have caused severe flooding and landslides across central and southeastern Mexico, affecting five states including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi. The death toll has risen to 44, with El Universal reporting 48, and dozens of people still missing. Around 320,000 people face power outages and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged. The Mexican government has activated the military to assist in rescue and aid operations, with President Claudia Sheinbaum emphasizing a commitment to no one being left without support. The event is linked to a broader pattern of extreme rainfall in Mexico, including Mexico City's rainiest June in over two decades.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
